title: Give warnings if variables have spaces in them in fixed-form
body:
The fixed-form source code ignores all spaces, so variables can have spaces in them. However we had a temporary limitation in LFortran that it didn't allow an `elsecs` variable and it turned out to be a bug in the source code, it was not intended to be such a variable. So LFortran could be giving warnings about such usage.

It might be quite a lot of work to actually implement such a warning, because the fixed-form prescanner drops all spaces, so that it is easier to handle in the fixed-form tokenizer. So by the time we notice it is a variable, we do not know if it had spaces in it or not. We would have to either figure out some way to do it, or fundamentally rework the fixed-form tokenizer.

It's a question whether it is worth investing into fixed-form, or rather use our resources to focus on free-form and only do the bare minimum needed for fixed-form so that LFortran can compile any older code.
